data.title: How Many People Work at Apple? Statistics & Facts (2024)
data.meta_description: Analyzing Apple's employment data, explore how many people work at Apple compared to previous years, shedding light on the tech giant's workforce.
data.text:
As of the most recent data from November 2023, Apple employs 161,000 individuals, marking a 1.83% decrease from the 164,000 staff members reported in 2022. This year represents the first instance of Apple's workforce not experiencing annual growth.

As of November 2023, Apple's workforce has grown by 17.52% since 2019, when the company had 137,000 employees. Despite this overall increase, the most recent data indicates a workforce of 161,000 individuals, reflecting a downturn from the previous year's higher figures.

What is Apple?

Apple Inc. is an American multinational technology company that was founded on April 1, 1976, by Steve Jobs, Steve Wozniak, and Ronald Wayne. Initially set on revolutionizing the personal computer industry, Apple introduced the Apple I, one of the first personal computers, and later the more successful Apple II. The company's innovation continued with the Macintosh, which popularized the graphical user interface.

Throughout its history, Apple has been known for pushing the boundaries of technology and design, leading to a loyal customer base and a reputation for premium products.

From its humble beginnings in a garage to becoming a global powerhouse, Apple has consistently been at the forefront of technological innovation. The company has expanded its offerings beyond personal computers to include mobile phones, tablets, wearables, and more, all while maintaining a focus on sleek design and user-friendly interfaces. Apple's recent endeavors continue to shape the tech landscape and influence consumer habits worldwide.

In recent years, Apple has continued to expand its product line and technological capabilities. The company has delved into services like Apple Music, Apple TV+, and the Apple Card, diversifying its revenue streams beyond hardware sales.

Apple's commitment to innovation is also evident in its recent developments in chip technology, with the introduction of the M1 chip, which powers a new generation of Macs and iPads. Additionally, Apple's focus on privacy and environmental sustainability has become a significant part of its brand identity, influencing product development and corporate practices.

The Executive Team at Apple

Let's take a look at the executive team behind Apple's success

Tim Cook, CEO

Before becoming CEO of Apple in 2011, Tim Cook held the role of COO and was responsible for the company's worldwide sales and operations. He also served as head of Apple's Macintosh division and played a key role in developing relationships with suppliers and resellers.

Katherine Adams, Senior Vice President and General Counsel

Katherine Adams joined Apple after serving as Senior Vice President and General Counsel at Honeywell, bringing extensive legal and corporate experience to her role overseeing Apple's legal matters.

Eddy Cue, Senior Vice President, Services

Eddy Cue has been with Apple since 1989, contributing to the creation of Apple's online store in 1998, and later the iTunes Store and App Store, leading the company's digital services to success.

Craig Federighi, Senior Vice President, Software Engineering

Craig Federighi returned to Apple in 2009 after working at Ariba and NeXT, bringing his software expertise to lead the development of macOS, iOS, and Apple's other operating systems.

John Giannandrea, Senior Vice President, Machine Learning and AI Strategy

John Giannandrea came to Apple from Google, where he led the Machine Intelligence, Research, and Search teams, to now drive Apple's AI and machine learning strategies.

Greg âJozâ Joswiak, Senior Vice President, Worldwide Marketing

Greg "Joz" Joswiak has spent over 20 years at Apple, holding various marketing and product management roles before leading the Worldwide Marketing division.

Sabih Khan, Senior Vice President, Operations

Sabih Khan has been with Apple for over two decades, working across various departments including product operations and supply chain management before becoming the Senior Vice President of Operations.

Luca Maestri, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer

Prior to joining Apple in 2013, Luca Maestri was CFO at Xerox and worked at Nokia Siemens Networks and General Motors, bringing a wealth of financial leadership experience to Apple.

Deirdre OâBrien, Senior Vice President, Retail

Deirdre OâBrien has over 30 years of experience at Apple, previously leading operations for Apple's hardware teams and HR, before taking on the role of Senior Vice President of Retail.

Johny Srouji, Senior Vice President, Hardware Technologies

Johny Srouji joined Apple in 2008 after working at Intel and IBM, where he gained expertise in semiconductor engineering, which he now applies to developing Apple's custom silicon.

John Ternus, Senior Vice President, Hardware Engineering

John Ternus has been part of Apple's engineering team since 2001, contributing to a variety of hardware projects before leading the Hardware Engineering division.

Jeff Williams, Chief Operating Officer

Jeff Williams joined Apple in 1998 as head of Worldwide Procurement and in 2004 took over Operations, playing a key role in Apple's entry into the mobile phone market with the iPhone.

Key Milestones in Apple's History

Here are some of the most pivotal moments in Apple's timeline:

The Location of Apple's Corporate Headquarters

Apple Park, the iconic headquarters of Apple Inc., is situated in Cupertino, California. This architectural marvel, often referred to as "the spaceship" due to its futuristic design, spans 175 acres and serves as a center for innovation and creativity. Officially opened in April 2017, Apple Park reflects the company's commitment to both environmental sustainability and aesthetic beauty, featuring extensive green spaces and powered by 100% renewable energy.

Top 10 Employee Benefits at Apple

Apple is renowned not only for its innovative products but also for offering its employees a range of impressive benefits. Here are the top 10 employee benefits that stand out at Apple:

1. Company-Wide Music Bashes

Apple hosts music events that are unique to the company, allowing employees to enjoy company-wide music bashes that celebrate their love for music and foster a sense of community.

2. Fertility Assistance

Apple supports its employees with fertility assistance, including services like egg freezing, helping to alleviate the financial burden for those looking to start a family.

3. Health Insurance Options

Employees can choose between UHC or Aetna health insurance plans, with or without an HSA, ensuring they have access to comprehensive health coverage.

4. Gym Access and Discounts

For a minimal fee of $9 per pay period, employees can use the on-site gym, promoting a healthy and active lifestyle.

5. Parental Leave

Apple offers generous parental leave policies, with up to 6 weeks for paternity leave and 16 weeks for maternity leave, supporting new parents in their journey.

6. Health Savings Account Contributions

The company contributes $750 annually to employees' HSAs, helping to cover out-of-pocket medical expenses.

7. Paid Time Off

Employees enjoy 12 days of paid vacation or personal time, along with 12 days of sick time, allowing them to rest and recharge.

8. Wellness Reimbursement

Apple encourages wellness activities by reimbursing up to $360 annually for gym or wellness expenses, equating to $30 per month.

9. Employee Assistance Program

This comprehensive program includes benefits such as accidental death and dismemberment insurance, free snacks valued at $730 annually, and access to gender-neutral bathrooms, among other support services.

10. Financial and Retirement Benefits

Apple's financial benefits include an Employee Stock Purchase Program with up to a 15% discount on stock, a 401k with a generous company match, and various accounts and plans to support long-term financial health.
